channel.title: Suggestions for Network Storage (NAS)
channel.description:
I'm looking to buy a Network Storage (NAS) solution within the next few weeks. Perhaps a custom-built? I am now finding internal hard drives for [url=http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16822136847]very, very cheap[/url] these days and I'd love to have access to such quantities of space. I was thinking about buying a small hard drive bay and then attaching some cheap hard drives to it. I'm not sure how this all works though, I'd have to do some research first...
If you have a NAS, what is your setup?

item.title: Suggestions for Network Storage (NAS)
item.dc:creator: @eXemplar eXemplar
item.description:
@eXemplar wrote:

I made like 500 spreadsheets mapping out the components I’d buy, but in the end it was just easier to outsource the effort - so I bought a qnap ts509 pro+

Read full topic

item.title: Suggestions for Network Storage (NAS)
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:4, topic:401721”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=498778.msg3647460#msg3647460 date=1309489566]
remember to mirror the drives, especially if youre gonna use super cheap ones</obligatory paranoia>

also speak to exemplar, he built a nice nas iirc
[/quote]

Last I talked to exemplar, he bought an almost $1000 dollar NAS pre-built.

Personally I’d just suggest just about any computer with at least a Gigabit NIC in it running Linux, that lets you have all the common share options (NFS, CIFS/Samba, FTP(please no), SFTP, about anything else you can imagine), and even if you don’t have an expensive hardware RAID controller, Linux’s software RAID is top-notch.[/quote]

$ df -h
Filesystem Size Used Avail Use% Mounted on
udev 10M 0 10M 0% /dev
run 10M 128K 9.9M 2% /run
/dev/sda3 7.3G 6.1G 900M 88% /
none 502M 0 502M 0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb 111G 207M 106G 1% /srv
/dev/sda4 67G 213M 63G 1% /home
/dev/sda1 38M 30M 6.3M 83% /boot
Thanks to you, I just remembered I had like 100GB of space on my server…

Read full topic

item.title: Suggestions for Network Storage (NAS)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:2, topic:401721”]remember to mirror the drives, especially if youre gonna use super cheap ones</obligatory paranoia>

also speak to exemplar, he built a nice nas iirc[/quote]

Last I talked to exemplar, he bought an almost $1000 dollar NAS pre-built.

Personally I’d just suggest just about any computer with at least a Gigabit NIC in it running Linux, that lets you have all the common share options (NFS, CIFS/Samba, FTP(please no), SFTP, about anything else you can imagine), and even if you don’t have an expensive hardware RAID controller, Linux’s software RAID is top-notch.

Read full topic

item.title: Suggestions for Network Storage (NAS)
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

if you are using it for storing data which you consider to be relatively important and that you dont want to lose I would suggest spending a little bit more, or if you want to use the cheap drives then do what mopman said and mirror the drives.

always mirror the drives if you want maximum security of data. but you dont have to i use raid5 on my “home-server box”, but i use some pretty decent hitachi drives.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:

remember to mirror the drives, especially if youre gonna use super cheap ones</obligatory paranoia>
